content.raw:
The Dockerfile should go right on the root of the repository, like in the example repo:

https://github.com/scpeters/src_field_computer_test

There's no need to scp any files into the field computer, CloudSim will do it for you when you launch the constellation.

The repo is not directly cloned on the field computer. We use the GitHub url provided to build the docker image with the following command:

`docker build -t fcomputer:latest <github_url>`

This is invoked the moment the machine is launched and depending on the size of your docker file, it might take several minutes to build. You can check that there is a process building the images with the following command:

`ps aux | grep "docker build"`

Once that is done, you can check that the image was built with:

`docker images`

which should show something like this (there might be more lines depending on your dockerfile):

~~~
REPOSITORY          TAG                 IMAGE ID            CREATED             SIZE
fcomputer           latest              4143b1f5e35c        43 seconds ago      954.7 MB
ros                 indigo-ros-base     f5fdd8d2a619        2 weeks ago         825.6 MB
~~~

Once that is finished, you can click the `START` button on CloudSim. That will run your container. You can check the container is running with:

`docker ps`

And it should show something like this:

~~~
CONTAINER ID        IMAGE               COMMAND                  CREATED             STATUS                  PORTS               NAMES
70a0992ae1b4        fcomputer           "/ros_entrypoint.sh p"   4 seconds ago       Up Less than a second                       team_container
~~~

We're working on adding more detailed instructions like these to the wiki.

content.raw:
I've done some naive research; I thought I would stash some notes here, in case it helps anyone else.  If not, I've wasted a whole mess of electrons.

But I noticed that if you go into cloudsim, you are given ami ids for the two images (ami-20133540 and ami-691d3b09).  You can then go into Amazon EC2, and even using 'free tier' machines, you can bring up those images (so long as you're in us-west-1), and then you can get a chance to poke around and try to figure out what is going on.  Unfortunately, the images themselves don't have much software on them; mostly a cloudsim tree that, in turn, uses tokens and urls to download other bits; I could not easily get those further downloads to work, so as to continue my forensics.

You do get a glimpse into how the cloudsim machines are meant to be constructed, and get a sense of how the vpn and other pieces will be built.  There is a nice mercurial repo with a lot of code; I bet a deep dive into that would shed some light on how the whole thing is meant to be built.

But I've exceeded my 'fiddle with VMs' time budget, and have to go pick things up with the hands now :-).

content.raw:
@dan77062 yes, the VPN link goes inside the field computer container. Inside the field computer docker container, the default `ROS_MASTER_URI` is set to the simulator IP so that the your code can talk to the simulator. I assuming you also want o use ROS for communication between OCU and field computer? To do this, you'll need to overwrite the `ROS_MASTER_URI` env variable in your script to the field computer IP before starting `roscore`, e.g.

Inside FC container, do:

~~~
ROS_MASTER_URI=http://192.168.2.10:11311 roscore
~~~

On OCU, after starting vpn:

~~~
ROS_MASTER_URI=http://192.168.2.10:11311 rostopic list
~~~

you should be able to get topics from FC

content.raw:
@vinayak_jagtap on the simulator machine, gazebo is run inside a docker container, so if you attach to the container you should be able to see the env variable, e.g.:

~~~
# attach to container
$ docker exec -it gazebo_run bash

# Inside docker container
$ env | grep ROS

ROS_MASTER_URI=http://192.168.2.1:11311
ROS_DISTRO=indigo
ROS_IP=192.168.2.1
~~~

On FC, you should not be able to talk to gazebo directly, ie `gz stats` wont' work, that's done on purpose.

I'll look into the problem with topics not publishing
content.html:

content.raw:
@dan77062. It's ugly but yes currently we expect the full deploy key to be pasted into the text field. 

I noticed I made a mistake in the wiki. The git url should begin with `git@` not `git://`. I've corrected it. Basically it'll be the same url you use with `git clone`

Can you try building the docker image locally using the deploy key method, e.g.

~~~
# Start the ssh-agent in the background.
eval "$(ssh-agent -s)"
# Add ssh key to agent
ssh-add <key_path>
# Add github to known hosts
ssh-keyscan github.com >> ~/.ssh/known_hosts
docker build -t fcomputer:latest <github_url>
~~~

content.raw:
@dan77062, how are you testing the connection to the FC docker container? The connection between FC and OCU should just go through the VPN tunnel and you shouldn't need to expose the ports. e.g.

1. download vpn keys from UI, extract it and start it on OCU: ` sudo openvpn --config openvpn.conf`

1. start FC container through the UI or run `fc_run_team_docker.bash` on FC

1. attach to FC docker container: `docker exec -it team_container bash`

1. Inside FC docker container, use `nc` to test port connection, e.g. : `nc -l 8002` (if you're using @scpeters dockerfile example, 8000 is already used by http server, and 8001 by roscore)

1. From OCU: `nc 192.168.2.10 8002`, type something and hit enter.

1. See the texts appear in FC docker container

1. you can test communication in reverse direction. i.e. `nc -l 8003` on OCU, and `nc 192.168.2.150 8003` on FC
content.html:
@dan77062, how are you testing the connection to the FC docker container? The connection between FC and OCU should just go through the VPN tunnel and you shouldn't need to expose the ports. e.g.

  2. start FC container through the UI or run fc_run_team_docker.bash on FC

  3. attach to FC docker container: docker exec -it team_container bash

  4. Inside FC docker container, use nc to test port connection, e.g. : nc -l 8002 (if you're using @scpeters dockerfile example, 8000 is already used by http server, and 8001 by roscore)

  5. From OCU: nc 192.168.2.10 8002, type something and hit enter.

  6. See the texts appear in FC docker container

  7. you can test communication in reverse direction. i.e. nc -l 8003 on OCU, and nc 192.168.2.150 8003 on FC

Just wanted to say we had our first success last night with the cloudsim.

We where able to get our field computer to run, connect to the simulation and completed task1. 

A couple of pointers:

* It really does take a LONG time for everything to build and setup. I would say it was about 20 minutes of poking before things where really running.  Clicking on the start buttons before things are build basically gives no useful feedback that nothing worked.  

* This may be flukes in our code but we had to have the simulation running or our field computer would freak out. And again starting the simulation was unreliable and you had no feedback if it was started or not.

* It did not feel like a very good real time factor. Lowering the harness took a lot longer than i thought.

All told in 1 hour real-time we where able to almost make it to the end of task1 and we shut everything down so as to not cost another hour of our budget. 30 minutes of things building and 20 minutes of performing actions.

Getting better feedback as to the status of the docker images would be really nice.  I did not see issues from Vinayak, but they are very concerning.

@dan77062 OCU <-> Sim communication is blocked so you won't be able to see Sim's roscore from OCU. You can have a separate roscore running on the FC but make sure you only set the ROS_MASTER_URI to the FC's IP address for processes that manage FC <-> OCU communication. For processes responsible for the Sim <-> FC communication, set the ROS_MASTER_URI to the sim's IP address. Note these are two separate channels and the nodes can't talk to each other.

@vinayak_jagtap we've seen some ihmc controller lockup issues / failed controller initialization on the cloud machine, we're looking into these issues. One PR has been merged recently to reduce initialization failures. We're also fixing the missing IP address issue.

@aricstewart glad to hear that you got it working. We've just rolled out a new release to block launching simulator until it's ready. The FC buttons will also be blocked until the the image is built. We''ll look into providing feedback about the simulator launch status.

@cmericli Hopefully the improved UI feedback and increased time allocation will help you with your testing on CloudSim.

content.raw: Why is sim<->OCU communication blocked?  Since they're accessible from the FC and therefore from our custom code, presumably the sim topics will be filtered to only give us information (like measured joint angles and sensor outputs) that the robot itself would be publishing real life.  Setting up another roscore to talk to the OCU and then piping joint state publisher, tf, etc all over from the sim roscore seems like an unnecessary complication, and one that is introduced solely by the simulated nature of the challenge (not to mention a lot of work to take on with only two weeks to go!).  Why not let the OCU computer also talk to the sim roscore?  Or let us run one roscore on the FC that talks to both the sim and the OCU?

Why not let the OCU computer also talk to the sim roscore? Or let us run one roscore on the FC that talks to both the sim and the OCU?

With the bandwidth restrictions and latency, I don't think ROS messaging has much of a chance of working over the OCU <-> FC connection.  Out of curiosity, has anyone gotten it to connect at the lower bandwidth settings?

Instead of doing that, we've been using separate ROS instances on the FC and OCU machines.  Each machine is running a node which acts as a bridge between its internal ROS messaging and the barebones message representations we send over the wire.

content.raw:
With low bandwidth and long latency delays, I think you'll need to carefully filter and relay messages over to the OCU from FC. You maybe able to get by with a max downlink of 2Mbit/s. However, with the combined effect of the 20s latency, you may start to notice issues (especially if using TCP). I think part of the challenge is to figure out the best protocol and method for communication.

For example, try simulate 10s outbound latency on your simulator machine:

~~~
# replace eth0 with your network interface
sudo tc qdisc add dev eth0 root netem delay 10000ms
~~~

and on another computer, `ping` should correctly give you a 10000ms latency. Now try echo some simulator ROS topics. The behavior may not be what you have expected.

when done, remove the `tc` rule:

~~~
# replace eth0 with your network interface
sudo tc qdisc del dev eth0 root
~~~

We could expose the simulator ROS topics to OCU but when the network restrictions kick in, I'm not sure how reliable they will be.

I think part of the challenge is to figure out the best protocol and method for communication.

sudo tc qdisc add dev eth0 root netem delay 10000ms

We could expose the simulator ROS topics to OCU but when the network restrictions kick in, I'm not sure how reliable they will be.

content.raw:
Found my problem. 

I had to copy the keys for my user account to the root account. Using sudo causes everything to be done in root's name. 

I also got a little closer to the proper syntax for the <github_url>  git@github.com:sringer99/srcsim.git. Notice the colon between the domain and the path. Still not if that is the only syntax that will work but it did work using this command after I copied the keys to the /root/.ssh/ directory. 

sudo docker build -t fcomputer:latest git@github.com:sringer99/srcsim.git

content.raw: @rmerriam, the docker build command we're running does not take the `-f` argument so the repo needs a top level `Dockerfile`. If your code looking for the sim's ros master? In that case, you can remove the `ENV ROS_MASTER_URI`, I think that was added in scpeters' Dockerfile as an example of starting a local roscore.

content.raw:
@rmerriam for practice, you can edit this file `~/code/cloudsim-sim/src_commands/fc_run_team_docker.bash` and redirect the docker run output to file, e.g.

replacing the last line with:

~~~
fcomputer |& tee -a $codedir/my_output.log
~~~

should generate a log file with docker container outputs in that directory after you hit the START button
